comments.body:
Thanks for the report.

I would call this non optimal play by the AI. Something that is hard to avoid without coding special cases and with so many cards that is simply undoable. The AI doesn't understand what Journey to Nowhere does, it only calculates scores for different actions. That will sometimes lead to decisions that a human opponent wouldn't take.

comments.body: I have also seen AI cast "mass destruction" spells when there are no valid targets. A 2RR spell that destroys all artifacts, or (if I recall) a 2W one that destroys enchantments.
comments.author: [jaze...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102707833900773093014/)

comments.body: Doesn't the AI consider 'not doing anything' a valid course of action? Doesn't it value having cards in its hand?
comments.author: [core...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/103434827021553153452/)

comments.body: Yes, passing is a valid course of action. Values are not associated with objects, rather values are associated with actions. These action values are accumulated to get the current value of a position. For example, the value of drawing a card is the value of the card. One issue might be that that putting a card into play doesn't take into account the lost of value of the card, it only looks at the gain in value of having the permanent in play.
